comments.text: The police helped me and asked drivers, they found quickly a lift to El Calafate for me

I had a ride straight through, but seems like a good spot. Don't carry anything illegal. Police were nice but searched my bags for drugs, even asking questions about vitamins and over-the-counter meds.
Be nice to the police guys...they ask the drivers to give you a ride.

This is the actual place of the Güer Aike police post. There are separate lanes for trucks and for cars. The policemen were super helpful. I talked to the truckers, they talked to the cars (very modestly and with style). In one hour they secured me a lift to Buenos Aires. These guys should get the Hitchhiker Friendliness Award when someone starts giving it.
Picked up after 2 minutes at the gas station heading south

At the YPF gas station, we got a ride south after 20min to Rio Cuarto.

A la gasolinera YPF, un camion nos tomó despues de 20min hasta Rio Cuarto.

Still a great spot in 2023, both roads with good traffic, can go both for Choele Choel and Neuquen, or for Buenos Aires!
Frequented by many trucks
Good confluence point to go either to Choele Choel and continue to Neuquen, or go to Buenos Aires the other road ,RN 251.
Found quickly a lift asking people at the gas station
Good spot, traffic going slow, Free wifi right there
The  bus stop to toll is between calle guemes y san martin like 10 blocks far away from train station bus price 12,50 pesos 12/2017 with sube card

Peaje de Espil: Hay que llegar a Luján, con tren desde Once, combinando en Moreno hasta Luján. 
En Lujan, bus 276 hasta el peaje de Villa Espil.
Se demora 3/4 horas en llegar desde Buenos Aires, pero el lugar es muy bueno.
No mas de 20 min de espera.
Good spot you find people to anywhere on the island. Try to get a direct ride and don't forget the border closes on at 10 sk you have to cross at least two hours earlier to make it to ushuaia

Waiting for the the ferry to to you over is a good time to   ask the drivers. Usaually most of them are going across the border and many all the way to Ushaia. So getting a driver that will take you there is simpler then being stranded out in the chilean wasteland, which is also fun if you want to get to know guanacos, sheep and oil workers
Candelaria es un lugar muy bonito para ir a Iguazu
Direction Piedrabuena, Puerto Santa Cruz, Gallegos - easy.
Easy - at least to Gregores and coast-bound (Puerto Santa Cruz, Rio Gallegos) - El Chalten and El Calafate will be tough due to the gravel road.
by the way, don't talk to the dogs here, unless you want to have a friend for life. they're cute though.
There's a YPF service station with Wifi, Cafe, toilets (closes around 10 pm). Northwartds to Bariloche and westwards to Chile Chico should work easily.
Great for Rio Grande and Ushuaia (it's the police post)... anything further north, ask drivers to bring you to the connection road bypassing Rio Grande.
The intersection where trucks bypassing the city come to, to go north as well as south.
Si vas a Neuquén, te conviene venirte hasta este cruce así agarrás a los que vienen desde Chile/La Angostura, funciona rápido! NO hagas dedo a la salida de Bariloche, es más dificil!
Almost no trucks. It isn't hard to get a ride here, but I prefer trucks because they travel farther. If you are going to Neuquén it is the best place.
car coming back to Ushuaia can give you a lift, but some of them can be already full. Do not start hitchhinking too late, earlier than 7pm possibly

Great spot after the toll stations. It´s call "peaje LIMA Zárate. Comming from Bs As, get the train at Villa Ballester train station and a bus at the same train station to the toll station. 

Excelente lugar pasando la estación de peaje. Se llama peaje LIMA Zárate. Viniendo desde capital federal, tomar el tren en estación Villa Ballester hasta Zárate. En la misma estación de tren está la estación de colectivos. Tomar un colectivo hasta el peaje, sobre ruta 9.

good place to hitch to the south of Santa Rosa,
30 min by walking from a bus station
South to Ushuaia, in which police checkpoint was a good ride point, visitors go to the room after passport registration, on the roadside waiting for the bus, 3 minutes to wait for the car.
Hitchhiked here to go to Chile and worked perfectly. The very first car was passing by stopped and they were going to Chile too.
Picked up within 30 minutes
YPF gas station 1 km away from the intersection with RP215
Super facil hacer dedo acá hacia Bariloche... no llegué a esperar 5 minutos... y fue fuera de temporada.
a las afueras del pueblo tienes espacios para que frenen los autos
Hay un Semaforo donde se puede hablar con los autos y van despacio
Cruce de caminos , la gente q sale de Ruinas del Quilmes y todos aquellos que vayan hacia Cafayate pasan por aqui
En toda la ruta 7 fuera de la ciudad preferentemente se pueden conseguir viajes muy facil , camiones , autos , etc

On the way south/north instead going to Rio Gallegos for a night stay in Camping PescazAike (close the stairs just after the parking). It's better than go into city and take a long walk next morning. On the roundabout cars need to slow down so it is easy to hike from there. But important thing there is no shops here.
Our destiny was San Rafael, and we didn't wait more than 15 minutes here!
I've been waiting for 20 minutes here in january, a saturday. A bus picked us up :)

Go on north on RN 3, gas station here.
Take a bus from the main bus station going to Pallazo standard.
On the corner where you get off there is a great panaderia :)
Picked up immediately. In my opinion a much better place than the toll station a few hundred meters before this gas station.

Great hitching spot if you are coming from Bs As and heading north towards Rosario. Bus 15 from the center (4.70 pesos in Feb 2015) will drop you off at this gas station, you may either talk to people or just thumb at the station exit, where there is plenty of space to pull over. We didn't have to wait for longer than 2 minutes, two other friends were also picked up immediately.
----- Bus 15 pasa por Palermo, Belgrano y te lleva hasta la estacion de servicio con 4.70 pesos (Feb 2015). Un buen lu

At the entrance to the road to Laguna Esmeralda there is a parking lot. This point is good to agree with a motorist if he returns to the city of Ushuaia or continue to Tohluin . And of course to hitchhike on route 3

At the toll on the 205 route is possible to hitchhike . It is recommended that the toll positioned on the shoulder and wait for a motorist . Or consult everyone who stops to use the public toilets of the place.

Paying gate (peaje) of La Paz. Not only great for hitchhiking in both directions, but also there is a 24 hour shop, free toilets and shower. Big truck parking space, also possible to get a ride by asking around.
El mejor lugar en el valle para hacer dedo. Muchísimos camioneros paran acá. También podés armar la carpa y descansar. Es muy tranquilo. Una parada obligada en mis viajes a dedo al sur.

Best place in the valley. The gas station is huge, always full of truckers heading towards Bahía Blanca, or Madryn or Trelew or Neuquén or Bariloche.
You can camp there too. The best place to rest if you been travelling all day. You'll get a ride very easily because MANY truckers stop there.
It took me less than 10 minutes to get a ride here. It was raining and I was just waitin there and a trucker stopped by and gave me a ride south.
It is a gas station. Lots of trucks. You'll get a ride easily.
Great place. Right after the roundabaout. Lots of trucks.
Provincial Police Checkpoint. Just ask the police if they can help us, they got us the first car that stopped.
Great gas station! Overnight place for Trucks, and also a very used gas station for cars, for fuel and food.

Good Spot. It's a gas station that has a lot of traffic.
If you prefer, you can walk to the roundabout, and choose to go north to Formosa/Paraguay or West to Salta and Chile

Peaje por rio cuarto.
como 15 km desde el centro de Córdoba.
Lamentablemente no sé como llegar aquí desde el centro, yo tení suerte que me acerco un amigo con su auto.el bus urbano 36/50y51 deberían parar 3,5/4km antes el peaje...
supongo debería estar un servizio de bus entre la ciudad de Córdoba hacia la ciudad de bower. normalmente esta siempre una parada cerca al peaje(averiguar a la estación) .
me levantaron al toque... ;)

peaje autopista, desde rosario tomar bus desde plaza sarmiento con destino carcarana(mas o meno 1,5 hora)frequencia cada hora, precio 25 ars 17/12/14. el bus te deja en la ciudad, tiene varias paradas...si me acuerdo bien la mas cercana esta entre av. sarmiento y escalada, pedir al chofer...,luego puedes caminar hacia el peaje  como 2,5 km por una calle sin asfalto.
Suerte! ;)
Checkpoint of Gendarmeria, they may help you finding a lift either to San Salvador de Jujuy, Bolivian border or Formosa. There is a petrol station nearby with a free shower.
Checkpoint of Gendarmeria. Speak with the officials and they can stop a truck for you. Lots of trucks from Paraguay going to duty free zone in Iquique, Chile.

Spot for hitching south to Formosa. Many Paraguayan trucks, most going all the way to duty free zone in Iquique in Chile. If someone offers you a lift to the checkpoint of Gendarmeria go for it, they can help you finding a lift with truckers.
This is the base to  reach the Chamapquí Peak. It's a 8 house village.You can find other hitchihikers and try to get a ride to come back to Villa General Belgrano.
This road is not so busy, but people is very kind in this place. Not so hard to find a ride and a smile. Even a lumber truck gave us a ride. If you are here, don't miss the Champaquí Mountain.
We were very succesful in this point. 3 rides in just one day!
Full of hitchhikers in the summer.
Are you starving? No money? We were very succesful asking for food in Capilla del Monte.
You can swim here and also camp if you really need.
Try this point. Just 3 blocks away from the main town square. Cars reduce velocity in this point and it's also one entrance from the route.
If you need a place to camp, just follow the river direction south. It´s quiet, clean water and woods.
If you need a ride in this zone, try this point. Cars reduce velocity here and it's also an entrance to the village.
Peaje Maipu... Very good. 60 km from Dolores.
i put me at the side before the cars payed, it's better. but be carefull, you have to fine someone which bring you a bit far because someone left me 3kms after, where there wasn't so many cars.
Peaje Autopista del Sol - Pacheco. Se llega desde Cap. Fed. con colectivos de lÃ­nea (60, 15, 21)
service area cuatro bocas. to buenos aires or to misiones. its a big area with petrol station. 20min waiting
This is next to a sea lion colony (you have to pay to see them), 14 km from P Madryn. You can walk to here along the beach (very nice walk on a nice day), and you can easily hitch a ride back.
RP1 to the east of here is actually closed (march 2013) and traffic goes around here, through the suburb to the south.
Peaje apenas pasando CaÃ±uelas, sobre RN3. Excelente para viajar haciar el sur. Para llegar desde BsAs. tomar el 88 en Plaza Once que va a San Miguel del Monte y pedir bajar en el peaje de CaÃ±uelas.
Control de cargas policial en GÃ¼er Aike. TODOS los camiones que van en ambas direcciones deben parar, es excelente! Pedirle a la policÃ­a que te consiga viaje.

peaje santa fe - rosario
buen lugar para hacer dedo, se llega desde santo tome caminando por camino al costado de la ruta
apenas pasan la rotonda hay un cartel de ruta, ahi pueden hacer dedo perfecto

Great occacion to approach the people waiting for the boat. Many of them are people crossing the border and all the way to Ushaia. So if you want to go all the way its better not to be stuck in the chilean wateland, but that is also interesting experience.

Waiting for the the ferry to to you over is a good time to   ask the drivers. Usaually most of them are going across the border and many all the way to Ushaia. So getting a driver that will take you there is simpler then being stranded out in the chilean wasteland, which is also fun if you want to get to know guanacos, sheep and oil workers
Short ride to get closer to the center.

We were warning to head north to Belén however no cars were going that direction so we got a ride to the road junction 20 minutes north. Many cars heading this way to the next town of Famatina. Once there we tried again

Lots of shade from trees, refreshments from the gas station. Picked up very quick by a local driving all the way. Many trucks stopped to take us halfway to the road that splits off to Chile border but that is in the middle of nowhere.
Good spot but quite a distance to walk out of the city
Easy ride place. Better than wait for buses. The rides drop me in the center of Neuquen twice.
Got a ride in like 5 minutes back to the city. Can also take a bus.

Great spot, but hard to reach! The spot itself is super efficient to hitch hike north on road 151 (to Mendoza, and before to San Rafael). If you stay on road 51 it is really easy to go far, huge traffic and lot of trucks and lot of space for car to stops :)
To reach it : in 2023 take the colectivos línea 2 from Centro of Neuquén, and take one that goes to Centenario (not all buses of línea 2 are going there). Ask the driver to leave you at a stop where you can take another bus that will take yo
Perfect stop to hitch-hike on road 3, heading south or north. Lot of trucks, and a huge gas-station with a lot of traffic!

Perfect spot to reach the roundabout up, wich crosses round 3. It is one hour by foot, but the wind can be extremly strong there.
If you are heading north, try asking your driver to leave you on the YPF gas station a bit further on road 3! Perfect spot to hitch-hike there
Super easy to get a ride from here to El Bolsón. Commuters do this road everyday both directions.
Tons of cars, oilfield company pick-ups and trucks passing through this spot towards Neuquén. Extremely easy place to get a ride.
YPF gas station is a very easy place to get a ride: after asking a few people, a nice dude took me from here directly to Bariloche.

Extremely easy spot to hitchhike towards Zapala, especially in high-season due to a lot of tourists are going to the Cordillera side.
Also, a lot of workers go and come from Neuquén to Zapala.
yet again, not 100% sure on the adress!

There are two buses from San Juan (uptown) that leave you in this place. The 109 Bus and the 19 Bus, both go for the main city street (Av.Libertador). Or you could take them in Bus Station. (Terminal). They are very cheap around US$1.
Good spot, plenty of place to stop. If you are hungry, thirsty of to hot, you can get shelter in the gas station accross the road.

Long walk (40 mins) from the town of Villa Unión. Little amount of shade near roundabout. No cars passing, we were very lucky that someone stopped. They original drove past us and then turned around 2 minutes after. Probably guilty about leaving us. Most locals apparently heading across to Chilecito early in the morning
Arrived around midday, no shade, cars driving fast. 2 hours later we got picked up.

We were two Backpacker going to direction SanJuan and Salta. The intersection is great spot and wide place to stop for cars. We got ride aroud 35 km to Lavalle. ( We realized there is a bus is going here Number 300 ,who want to get a bit far from citycan consider this option) 
There is a Police check point in This town which cars stop too. 

We might say hitchiking is tough in Argentina and takes long times, drivers most of time does not seems friendly.
Good spot to go north

After a bunch of cars, a chilean young couple picked us up (2 people), and took us directly to Osorno, which was our destination.
Easy spot to get a ride, mostly in Summer time.

If you travel by approaching drivers at fuel stations, this is the place. If you're using only thumbs on the roadside and trying to go north (as I was), stand across the "circunvalacion" (bypass road) from the fuel station, where traffic from both southwest and northeast is funneled into the northward route. This was where I got the most reactions (and eventually a ride), even with the sun at my back. And if you're not using the fuel station to approach drivers, consider accepting a ride that ju
Good for both Ushuaia and Rio Gallegos (and Rio Grande center of course).

I got so insanely lucky here. 1212km in one truck. Stood with a sign waiting, many cars going in the right direction, the truck stopped to let somebody out and I asked him where he went and well 24 hours later I was in Mendoza
Had a lot of luck here and got a ride in a pickup truck aaaaalll the way to Rosario
The gas station is a good place to get a ride as well, as there are plenty trucks and cars
Got dropped off here on my way from Jujuy to Salta. Plenty of green space and tall grass to camp, big petrol station to wash and re-supply and lots of traffic to continue to Salta.
Got a ride to Tolhuin fast enough, thumb only, in the afternoon, in the winter. I stood a ways past the control booth, beyond the city entrance gate.
Take the bus and get a easy lift! Was on my way to the border in 10mins from where i got an easy ride to punta arenas ... OCT 2017
Bus B has its last stop there
I got a ride after 10 minutes standing outside the city gate after the 'control' with a sign reading "Rio Grande por favor!"
The entrance and exit. You will eventually get hit. Jump around to keep warm and get pity points.

This is not the actual location of the border posts - the Chilean control is several kilometers west, and the Argentine one is about 15km east. I didn't actually hitchhike here (my ride from Rio Grande took me all the way through), but the border officials on both sides have no problem with you telling them you're hitchhiking. As of 2025 there's theoretically a hotel near each border post, in case you get stranded and have money.
mm...it's not the best spot, but two days? It took us maybe two hours - not a big deal. the chilean post is a bit better.

just wait in the heated waiting room, looking through the window to see when a car approches the border check point and ask to the driver. We got a lift at the first car at 6.30am towards north. Ferries starts at 8am

border of san sebastian. i waited 2 days, border guards are nice though and let us sleep in the unused office. there is a small town a couple kms towards chile, don't walk there and hitch from there. drivers more likely to pick you up at the border, especially if you talk to them
R.N. 14 to the North

Got a late afternoon ride to Rio Grande in the winter in about half an hour, thumb only. I think I stood about 100 meters north of where the dot is, where the wide street meets the highway from the northwest, though the ride came from the highway itself.
An YPF gas station good for hitching both directions.

I wasn't allowed to ask in the gas station for rides, but stood with a sign saying "Carretera dirección Cordoba / Jujuy" to go to the real highway on the opposite site of the road and sure enough a pickup truck stopped after some 15min

The petrol station is a bit further down as marked in the map. I asked around for about an hour and than took a lift to the highway tool. Best get out here quick as there is still a lot of local traffic.
There is a petrol station which cars have to pass, which are going out of the city. You can find a ride to the South and to the North as well.
Caleta olivia is very possible better thatpn the petrobas before
Going South. A ride until Caleta Olivia shouldn't be hard to get if you don't give up!
Speed is low and enough place to stop a trucks.
Ok spot lots of traffic a bit down after the crossing truckers are stopping to get food just try to ask. Took me one hour to get to azul .... Monday morning
If you are heading to Patagonia, it might be worth it to take the cheap train to Bahia Blanca and start hitching from there. It will save you the hassle of getting out of Bs As
Good point to travel direction to North.

Peaje de Nelson. Good place for hitchhiking North to Resistencia. How to get here: take a bus at the Station in Santa Fé to Nelson. It will cost around $ 40 pesos (U$ 4). Ask the driver you want to stop in the Peaje. Couple of meters North the Peaje there is a gas station, which is also a good place to ask for a ride.
Утром в будний день подобрали почти сразу по дороге вглубь Аргентины.
All the cars going to the south cross this point.
All the cars going to the south cross this point, so it's easy to find one. You can sleep at the end of the av. maria auxiliadora, there is cheap camping with hot water.

peaje rosario. find a ride in 1,30 min.
to get here take a bus from rosario`s bus station to general lagos,the bus it s call M verdeyou can get it just outside the bus station, ask to the driver because they have  2 kind of M verde, ask for the one which go to general lagos going to hightway,just get off when the bus turn left leaving the hightway to general lagos,then just walk something like 1,5 km until the boot toll;)
bus price 16 pesos (09-15)
good luck!
roberto gh
Peaje  Gral Lagos o Arroyo Seco. Colectivo: Tirsa Y la M azul te traen desde Rosario o San Nicolas.~$4(2007)

desde la terminal mendoza tomar bus con destino la paz y pedir al chofer de bajar por esta estacion de servicio que es muy conocida,despues que bajan del bus caminar como 1 km hacia el lugar precio bus 21 pesos

Estacion de servicios Eloy Guerrero. Genial para hacer dedo, conseguís para todos los destinos, incluyendo para Chile. Se llega desde Mendoza en colectivo (9 pesos) hasta San Martin y luego otro (4 pesos) y hay que caminar unas 10 calles por un camino de tierra.

Not bad, ended up waiting 2 hours and then walking out to the service station a little beyond town.  Picked up within 20 minutes of getting there by a trucker.  Truckers take this route very often to get to BA

at the end of the town,
last stop of the bus route 720 which brings you here from Mar del Plata
En medio de la ciudad pero pasan todos los autos que sigan por la ruta 7 , no es necesario caminar hasta la salida de la ciudad
Going South. At least a lift until Comodoro Rivadavia it shouldn't be hard to get asking around.
going south, it is hitchable on truck

nto Nueva Galia's entrance there's a small plaza where you can go camping!  I've sleep one night there, and the other day was sunday, which was kind of difficult to hitchhike, we've waited 2 hours. Then a truck drove us for more than 300 km !

Into Nueva Galia's entrance there's a small plaza where you can go camping!  I've sleep one night there, and the other day was sunday, which was kind of difficult to hitchhike, we've waited 2 hours. Then a truck drove us for more than 300 km !
Two locals from Realico picked me and my friend up after 10 minutes waiting. Although there isn't too many cars here.
Para viajar desde San Rafael a General Alvear, hacer dedo en la Avenida Alberdi. Esta es la ruta que la mayoría  toma para llegar a esa ciudad.

The Peaje located in AutoPista 01. Considering stand after the peaje where cars go slow. The only problem is to get there from Rosário. There is a bus from Rosário but it drives you until Peaje San Lourenço, few KM before.

Good place! There is a gas station one side of the road and a logistic company another side where a lot of trucks get in and get out, going to Ruta 9. We talked with some of them and we got a ride in 15 min until Rosário.

t the exit of the roundabout on Route 205 toward Bolivar , there is a restaurant , from there you can hitchhike . In the shoulder there is room for vehicles to stop. Taking a distance of 100-150 from the roundabout .
Muy buen lugar. Conseguí que me lleven hasta Choele Choel esa misma noche y eso que era muy tarde.
It is a gas station. Lots of trucks stop here. You'll get a ride to Neuquén or Bahía Blanca very easily. Also you can camp there.

Nao pode atravessar a fronteira a pé, por isso, peguei carona em frente a imigracao brasileira até a imigracao argentina. depois, saindo da imigracao argentina (na rota indo pra Buenos Aires) pode pegar um coletivo até o proximo posto (opcao mais segura) ou tentar carona ali mesmo, como fiz.
Good spot with plenty of space for cars to stop. The sun can be a problem, and maybe on the other side of town you can get help from the Police or Gendarmeria.
lugar bom para pegar carona para Rio Turbio
Pode pedir carona para o sul até Ushuai no astação de serviço El Cholo.
I dont remember exactly the spot but there is a small Gas station there, we actually slept on the back door, there is some green area and after asking the owner of the place wont have any problem
Hitchhiked from Jujuy towards Tilcara, it took a while to walk out of the city on the motorway and then about an hour to get a ride, but once I got going it was fine.
There is a petrol station situated, where you can find rides to Chile as well as to the north of Argentina and Bolivia.
i think the best way to go to the north is to take a bus until here from buenos aires. its quiet cheap.
There is a peaje station, where you can stop cars are talk to the drivers and there is a petrol station very close by.
Hay una rotunda acá donde se puede hacer dedo para El bolsón... lo hice en mayo, fue muy facil, no esperé nada!
Good place to hitch-hike to Uruguay direction.

From here you can hitchhike to Buenos Aires. But NEVER ever accept to go to Zarate if you're going to Buenos Aires. It's fucking hard to hitchhike from the Zarate junction to Campana (which is on the way to Buenos Aires), it's better to stay a little more here and keep trying to find someone who can take you a longer way.
hike for south on truck, some can even take two backpackers with big backpackers
Place to go to the south. In the middle of crossroad is some building (tourist office or something like this).
Gas station - YPF. Good place to go to south, north and west.

Peaje de San Luis, un lugar muy bueno para hacer dedo en la ruta Mendoza-Buenos aires (o viceversa!). Hay muchisimo trafico de camiones. Incluso hay un gran parador donde los camioneros duermen por la noche.
dedo por ruta 70 hacia esperanza

We were running out of water standing here by the bridge, only 6 cars per hour over the time of 11am - 1pm. Many cars either full of not responsive. A trucker from Famatina picked us up the whole route.
Quizas el mejor lugar para esperar en direction de santa fe. Hecho el error de acceptar hasta rio primero y despues fue muy muy difficil de llegar hasta santa fe…
Not the best spot talking of visibility, but I think the best there is in this area

Its in the middle of nowhere but traffic has to drive a bit slower because of the intersection. Arrived at night, camped close to there, was fine but a bit windy
Not too much traffic but still enough
good spot if you wanna go to the interiror of the province
Llegué a Bowen en micro desde San Rafael y caminé a este lugar. Está frente a un estación de servicio donde para mucha gente. Me llevó un camionero hasta Nueva Galia.
Easy spot to hitchhike: a lot of cars going towards El Chocón, Picun Leufu, Piedra del Aguila and Bariloche.
I hitchhiked from here to Caviahue. Super easy: first car passing by picked us up. Be careful: Not many cars doing this way after 5 p.m. though.

Easy spot to get a ride, but a bit cold at night. Mostly locals who belong to rural areas usually drive it, and they're very friendly.
It took me 30 min to get into a car because it was already dark at 20:30 and not many cars were around (to not say there was nobody around) but the first car passing by picked me up and took me to the next destination.

arco lugar con control fijo de gendarmería. Los auto dajan velocidad y es un buon lugar en ambas direcciones norte por puerto iguazu y sur oeste por corrientes.desde la ciudad posadas puedes tomar un bus preguntando de parar al arco.precio 30 pesos 7/2/15.también la gendarmería mismo me ayudó. Encontré  un pasaje hasta corrientes capital en 30 min
aduana de camionero, bastante bueno el lugar, con camionero normalmente se consigue hacia los andes en chile porque ellos tienen que parar en la aduana chilena que se encuentra aen los andes
not 100% sure about the location... you'll find it :-)

really, really good spot to get over the Andes to Chile and directly to Santiago. My original plan was to go South but I had no luck finding a car going there so I ended up taking an offer to go west.
The employees at the fuel station are nice but the won't allow you to ask the drivers directly.

Ideal para ir hasta Uspallata/ Chile.
Importante: no pararse a Potrerillos. Encontrar alguien que va directamente hasta Uspallata.
cars come past this spot very quickly and much fewer cars go north from here as it gets less touristy but still possible
there is now wifi in this spot as well, very exposed so quite windy but cars slow down when turning to el chalten
sheltered spot. buses will pass by daily and plenty of traffic in the summer
I've heard it is tricky to get to El Chalten. Other directions should work. To the north there will be a 100 km of gravel - so not everyone goes there.
some days the first car will pick you up, others you will have to wait 20ish minutes
okay

You'll want to get to this place if you're hitchhiking to Rio Gallegos or Punta Arenas without approaching drivers at fuel stations. But be aware that there is no fuel station here, and it's a bit of a walk to any shelter. Stand where cars are coming out of the "rotunda" (roundabout) headed northwest. I failed to get a ride here in the late afternoon, but then succeeded the next morning (with snow coming down hard - maybe I got some pity points). Ride was headed all the way to Gallegos, and even

not so bad, but not so good either. direction Rio Gallegos, you will have to eventually go here or you wait on the connection road before Rio Grande. Do not get inside the city! Use that connection road going to the Airport and Laguna de los Cisnes.
Neste lugar existe uma balança destivada onde se pode pedir carona para sair da ilha.
Worked perfectly for me right there, first car that came took me to go north direction Piedrabuena

Guer Aike could be your spot if you need to go north from Rio Gallegos or if you came from the west (El Calafate, Rio Turbio). I'd recommend you wait at the police station; those guys actually tried to help me. I, stubbornly, walked through a huge construction site (Dec 09) and got lost in a maze of intersections, before I stumbled upon the right road by sheer luck and finally managed to thumb a ride on the roadside after an ordeal of several hours. Again, stay at the police post, you might also
Spot looks great, many cars passing by, lots of space to stop and a good view, but it's horrible! No one picks you up here. My ride only got my 3km further and they were two travellers aswell.

Tanto para Mendoza quanto para o Chile (a rota que a maioria faz), esse é um bom ponto. Há alguns mochileiros que param por aí pra buscar carona. O fluxo nao é intenso, mas a quantidade que para é maior... Aprox. umas 10h sai com duas amigas pra pegar carona: elas para Mendoza e eu para o Chile. No primeiro levantar de dedos, elas conseguiram carona com um caminhao e eu, depois de meia hora, consegui com uma familia...direto para Santiago. O unico ponto  que pode ser um problema é a fronteira AR
Good a ride to rio colorado 10 at night monday ... Service statiln rodovia just at the turnoff

This is the wost place to hitchhike I've ever had. We spend there a WHOLE DAY with no luck at all. The truck drivers are totally sick of backpakers and dont even talk to you. The people from the station try to make you out (during a small time was raining like hell and we came in just like anyone else will do) and if you take the same day of the train from Buenos Aires arriving prepare yourself for being 20 hitchhikers on the road.

As i said we spent a whole day, not joking we had to sleep ther

Should be near a truck stop called "El Choro". There's a parilla called "El Gordo" here. Go and ask to buy bread, if you play your cards right the owner will come out and say "every mochilero who comes here eats for free" then you get a whole bunch of awesome Argentine BBQ. It was awesome.
started early that day - no problem. heard on sundays there are up to 10 hitchhikers on the road here.
countless hitchhikers queued and bad HH mind of drivers, some of them were waiting for longer than a day
after a police control station. cars slow down. some were maybe a bit reluctant to pull up when the police can see them.
For me it was a great spot to get to the North, Calafate and Rio Gallegos. I've heard it's tough on sundays.
gave up after 2 days waiting
good place
Out of season (end of May): fairly easy to hitchhike in, extremely hard to hitchhike out. Gave up after 1 day, a girl succeded after 3 intense days of hitchhiking 8 to 18.
Easy to get in and hard to get out, because of high conpetition and few cars
Terrible for Buenos Aires trips. Lots of trucks going to Cordoba.
Alejandose un poco de la ciudad se vuelve facil conseguir viaje
many hitchhiker queued for a lift, many cars driving to the glaciar but only few of them with HH mind
to go to Perito Moreno. Get out of the centre and there are speed bumps so people drive slowly. Coming back from Perito Moreno is also easy.

There´s a GNC gas station. If you want to avoid entering Rosario. It´s not easy but you´ll get a ride strait to Córdoba allong route 9.

Hay una estación Petrobras donde se puede hacer dedo si quieren evitar entrar a Rosario. No es fácil y lleva tiempo pero se consigue viajar hasta Córdoba
Got picked up mostly through luck, and a very nice apple seller.
Have a spots of trucks that will go to Chile or Brazil. In the Street Ridrigez PeÃ±a have a Petrol station that have a lot brazilians drivers.
Took some time, but eventually got picked up by a couple of French travellers in their rental car
less traffic here, but still some going to Cafayate, expect an hour or longer. Plenty of green space to camp.
A crossroad of the 40 with a dirtroad to Cerro Castillo.
Hay un control policial , pero pasan muy pocos autos y camiones  , de todos modos se puede
En medio de la ruta , no hay nada , pero los autos pueden parar
Hay una estacion de servicio , los autos frenan aqui , pero igual es dificil , hacia Bolivia
Salidas del pueblo
No hay nada cerca , todos los autos que van a Tafi del Valle pasan por aqui , pero es muy dificil
En las afueras del pueblo , muy dificil conseguir viajes largos
Hay banquina para que paren los autos , pero hay muy poco trafico fuera de temporada
THE place to hitch if you're going south from Caleta Olivia. Food street vendors, space for truck stop... if you're lucky you can get a direct truck ride to Rio Grande or Ushuaia!

We try go to Pasadas from Puerto Iguza. First stop - oil station at the end of city, second - near from enter to Iguzu park. After we walk to direction Pasadas and sudenly us pick up couple from Paragvay. By the way, first and second place not bad, simple we wait not long time.

Smaller petrol station. During lunchtime, big traffic in both directions (Santa Fe or Córdoba). Ask people where they are going. 
In the afternoon, traffic is scarce, in the direction of Córdoba it is better to stand on the other side of the road with a sign (very important, use a sign) and wait for drivers coming from the road opposite from the station.
Bad place. No one stops near the police control.
Para ir al sur, hacer dedo en la ruta 143, pasando Granaderos, ya que se aprovechan tanto autos que van por la Ruta y camiones que doblan desde Granaderos.
90% of the cars are not going far, we were stuck there for quite a while until someone gave us a lift past the 105 turning. After that we got a ride very easily half way to Iguazu.
La Garita,(dsde Posadas en bus). Empalme RN12 (para ir a Iguazu) y RN105 (para Corrientes).
There´s a petrol station with plenty of space for cars to stop, you can also ask drivers.
More traffic goes towards Santa Maria, so if you want to go to Amaicha del Valle, it´s harder. I walked in the direction for about 1 hr, then got a lift.
Takes almost two hours to walk out of the city, but then there´s a wide road with plenty of space for cars to stop, and enough traffic, although it took almost an hour to get a ride.
Takes almost two hours to walk out of the city, but then there´s a wide road with plenty of space for cars to stop, and enough traffic, although it took almost an hour to get a ride.
I waited on this spot for about 1 hr, no luck, then kept walking in the direction for another hour and eventually got picked up.

to get to Punta Ninfas and see the elephant seals. Three cars passed in two hours. One of them was going only half way to an estancia. On a weekend some locals seem to drive there to have a bbq. It might be a better idea to share a rental car with other people. The gravel road is bad, but doable in a normal car, unless it has been raining very heavily.
You can hitchhike along this street. Local people said it's comun here. Then you can get a ride to Ruta 14, where's a better place to hitchhike to the city you want.
Just start walking and hope you get lucky. It's not necessary to go to Tres Lagos, in fact probably better not to, expect a long ride. The road was in the process of being paved early 2012.
Gas station YPF

very slow going on a rainy sunday morning in Dec09 - got a ride up north after 3-4 hrs, but that's mainly because there wasn't much traffic on the road and even less using this petrol station (except people from Puerto San Julian going back there)

Way on south (Rio Cuarto).
Salida al Sur (Rio Cuarto).
Выезд на юг (Рио Кварто).
Way on the south. Gas station - YPF.
Leave space behind you for a truck ;-)
Be careful, many times the end of the lift is the the middle of nothing.
Desde aquÃ­ se pude viajar a Catamarca se llega en colectivo de la linea 12 (BÂº Autonomia). Justo antes hay una lomada por lo que los vehÃ­culos circulan despacio.
Desde aquÃ­ se puede llegar hasta Termas de Rio Hondo o Tucuman Por Ruta 9. No hay linea urbana para llegar hasta este lugar

Route 14 - Buenos Aires

We were two and as we failed we decided to split and after that we find ride in 30-60 minute. 
Be insist with your tumb to truck drivers. 
If you are lucky you can find a ride to Capital but most of cars split after Zarate so if you stuck in Zarate intersection ask people for 194 Bus station which is 3500 Pesos. 

As we experience waiting long time is common in Argentine.

If you want the 40 Go to where only the 40 is left. 
A nice Woman Took us to las lajas
After a Long day of trying to get a Ride, a wonderful mother and her Child Tool us to Zapala
Dirty road the cars are slow but i still waited a lot before being picked up

Spot is okay, people goes a bit too fast but long road and place to stop for cars. Reachable in bus, line 611 i believe, to El Borbollon. There is a gas station also near. Mendoza is hard to get out from, i think here you are pretty sure to leave. Not a lot of camions though

First tried to hitchhike north from here at 1pm, and failed utterly - gave up after three or four hours in the freezing wind, trying various spots in the immediate area. Came back next morning at about 11am and got a ride all the way to Puerto San Julian where I had a couchsurfer waiting for me. I recommending standing west of the highway interchange, as cars are emerging from it. Under the bridge some of the cars will be going slower, but the ones coming from town are in the wrong lane and the
Waited 5 hours, bad spot. Not sure if there's a better one. Generally visibility is good, but idk still nobody took me.
Tentei por um dia inteiro pegar carona, porém somente 3 caminhões pararam para perguntar para onde iria e nenhum quis me dar carona (eu ia para Rosario Santa Fé). Tive que ir de onibus até Eldorado
The spot seemed right - an exit road with a wide roadside comfortable for pulling over and a speedbumps slowing traffic but after 4 hours I was still there. Did I picked up a wrong day?

Кажется, как будто отличное место, чтобы ехать - в Мисьонес: до аэропорта ходит городской автобус, прямая дорога на север  (Рута Досе). Но на практике меня никто не брал часов 6. Плюс-минус 500 метров не в счёт. Дело было в выходной день в январе, орды народа ехали со всеми детями и до ближайшего пляжа, наверное, дело в этом. Ещё здесь на меня напали какие-то чудовищные жёлтые гусеницы. Бойтесь жёлтых гусениц - они организованы и оставляют болезненные ожоги!
Not the best place to try and grab a ride, but got picked up anyway by a guy who felt sorry for me.
Pueblo pequeño , muy poco trafico , muy dificil , tramos muy cortos
Estuve 1 dia y medio y no consegui que nadie me llevara , en julio . Tuve que tomar un bus a Neuquen . Es preferible ir por la ruta desde Bariloche a Neuquen
A las afueras del pueblo , la ruta permite que frenen autos
Even with a sign, we had to walk to the traffic light and still waited a long time. Best maybe to walk accross to the other exit of the town, or ask to be left there.
Not a good spot going West. It's the entrance of the city, and most cars stay there. Looks good going any other direction.
Though there are a lot of cars getting in and out from de town, it is not so easy to get a lift out. You better walk to Ruta Nacional 3, which is about 3 km straight.

Nunca pararse aquí si van en dirección de Usspallata/ Chile.
Los auto que salen de Potrerillos van todos en dirección de Mendoza. Y los que pasan por la autopista van demasiado rápido.

Una gran cantidad de camiones salen del puerto para ir en todo el país.
Ir a discutir con los camioneros directamente en los diferentes semáforos.
El problema: están apurados y no hay muchos lugares para que se paran.
Muy dificil , pocos autos , muy cerca de la frontera , no consegui que nadie me lleve , el pasaje en bus es muy economico

Alright. We need to talk about this place, because you will eventually end up here, if you are heading North to South on the 40. One thing first: Most cars will head to the coast since they try to bypass the 100 km gravel road towards Tres Lagos. When I arrived I met another hitchhiker who already waited two days to get to Chalten and then decided to take the bus. I waited here from 12 pm til 8 pm, then headed to the free Municipal Camping. Next day from 5 am til 2pm no ride to Tres Lagos: Many

Let's be clear: anything on this road will be tricky. It's mostly local traffic. Only option: walk as far as you can, passing the big Carrefour and the bus terminal (maybe you can bribe the driver to bring you to the police post?). Took me four hours to get to the police post, but then no problem at all into any direction I wanted. You could try to write a big banner saying: bring me to the police post or so.

it might look sensible place to El Calafate (there are trucks coming out petrol station on the near parallel road), but people running in that area are not used to hitchhiker and we got few unfriendly middle fingers in a couple of hours...
Si te encontrás acá, mejor andá hacia Plottier o Allen en colectivo. Es imposible que te lleven a ningún lado acá.
Worst place ever. Too near the cities.

Never ever EVER ask for rides here. There are 3 lines here, the cars and the trucks passes REALLY fast and there's NOTHING for the next kilometers. I've been hitchhiking with a friend here (we're 2 boys) and we started to walk towards the road trying to find a best spot but THERE ISN'T ANY! We walked (stopping and putting our thumbs up along many spots on the road) for like 3h30min until suddenly a man had to stop the car to change the wheel and we offered him help and asked for his help/ride.

We gave up after most cars heading north on this road were just to small neighbourhoods, many people told us our trip up to Belén was too far. We tried again further up the road the next day. There way shade here and cars were going to a town called Famatina.
november-just a few cars and nobody evens cared.

The direction Buenos Aires! 14
We were two Backpacker from Germany and Turkey (male) waited here almost 2 and half hour . After we failed we decided to split and we went under the bridge which Cars slow down and they come over bridge so after moving under the bridge finding ride was better as a solo!
Horrible!  Nobody stops on that road. After 6 hours a short ride in direction Cordoba. It was much better when I waited in the desert
Very long waiting time. No one stops, even though there is room to. The people that picked me up told me it's very rare to hitch hike in Mendoza, so they're not used to it.
I was trying to go to salta true the mountain road. They where some traffic but nobody took me. I ended up camping there and going another direction the next day
